data.title: Uncaught Error: Cannot read property 'object' of undefinedTypeError: Cannot read property 'objec...
data.body:
Hello
I just get this "Uncaught Error" error when saving a NodeJS file (changed a `Buffer.alloc` to `Buffer.from`).
I tried to reproduce the error by doing the same steps but I didn't succeed.

I will update the issue if I can find more details.

EDIT: it seems we found the issue of the day: #14441 #14443 #14447, Atom did not found the issue was already created.


**Atom**: 1.17.0 ia32
**Electron**: 1.3.15
**OS**: Unknown Windows version
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
TypeError: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
    at ObjectsRegistry.get (C:\Users\sfa\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.17.0\resources\electron.asar\browser\objects-registry.js:41:28)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (C:\Users\sfa\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.17.0\resources\electron.asar\browser\rpc-server.js:306:31)
    at emitMany (events.js:127:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:201:7)
    at WebContents.<anonymous> (C:\Users\sfa\AppData\Local\atom\app-1.17.0\resources\electron.asar\browser\api\web-contents.js:222:13)
    at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)
    at WebContents.emit (events.js:191:7)

```

TypeError: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
    at ObjectsRegistry.get (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.17.0/resources/electron.asar/browser/objects-registry.js:41:28)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.17.0/resources/electron.asar/browser/rpc-server.js:306:31)
    at emitMany (events.js:127:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:201:7)
    at WebContents.<anonymous> (~/AppData/Local/atom/app-1.17.0/resources/electron.asar/browser/api/web-contents.js:222:13)

    at WebContents.emit (events.js:191:7)

data.title: Install dev dependencies when transpiling
data.body:
This is to allow us to move babel and other dependencies used only during transpiling to dev dependencies so that we can reduce the size of our build artifacts. 

Ref https://github.com/atom/github/issues/638

data.title: Update docker image and add docs
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

<!--

We must be able to understand the design of your change from this description. If we can't get a good idea of what the code will be doing from the description here, the pull request may be closed at the maintainers' discretion. Keep in mind that the maintainer reviewing this PR may not be familiar with or have worked with the code here recently, so please walk us through the concepts.

-->

This PR changes the Dockerfile base image to node:6 which is the current LTS version of node. Following the build instructions in the documentation for linux, the image will be built with alle the requirements for building atom. At the same time, I added a little documentation for how to build and use the image.

Difference from the original Dockerfile image is the ADD and WORKDIR instructions in it, I decided to remove this and instead instruct to mount atom in the docker run command as the filesystem can change. 

### Alternate Designs

<!-- Explain what other alternates were considered and why the proposed version was selected -->

1. One might consider adding ADD and WORKDIR instructions back to Dockerfile.
2. #14225 only fixes the current failures with the current docker setup, and can be considered an alternative to this PR.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

<!-- Explain why this functionality should be in atom/atom as opposed to a package -->

Because it expands on features in core.

### Benefits

<!-- What benefits will be realized by the code change? -->

Docker makes it easy to build atom on any system that have Docker installed, without the need to handle dependencies for atom itself.

### Possible Drawbacks

<!-- What are the possible side-effects or negative impacts of the code change? -->

I'm not sure, as I do not know to what extent the Dockerfile is used in core or what purpose it had originally.

### Applicable Issues

<!-- Enter any applicable Issues here -->

Fixes #14394 
Fixes #14224
Closes #14225

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: this.getActivePaneContainer(...).activateNextPane is not a function
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. Open a dock (I used the sidebar, but this works in any dock)
2. Trigger `window:focus-next-pane`

expected:
EITHER
1) Next pane/dock is selected
2) Nothing happens, as dock only has one pane

actual:
The below error happens.

**Atom**: 1.17.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.3.15
**OS**: Mac OS X 10.12.4
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: this.getActivePaneContainer(...).activateNextPane is not a function

```
At /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/workspace.js:1559

TypeError: this.getActivePaneContainer(...).activateNextPane is not a function

    at atom-workspace.window:focus-next-pane (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/src/register-default-commands.js:168:1)

data.title: Atom 1.18.0 Beta Linux CI Travis build fails. GLIBC not found.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom 1.18.0 Beta Linux CI Travis build fails. GLIBC not found.

### Steps to Reproduce

See https://travis-ci.org/gandm/language-babel/jobs/233108682

**Expected behavior:** 

To Run & pass.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Doesn't run

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
Using APM version: ???

    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Since updating to Atom 17 (earlier today) typing got weird when a new dock appears.

Linter package now uses the dock at the bottom to show errors and warnings. Every time this new dock appears, the main view either looses focus or lags behind, with the effect that a few keystrokes are lost

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install Linter package 
2. Open a valid JS file
3. Start typing some rubbish quickly
4. Linter will start complaining
5. Notice how some of the characters you pressed don't appears on screen

**Expected behavior:** Every key press should end up in the editor

**Actual behavior:** I get upset

**Reproduces how often:** Every single time the lint dock shows up

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Linter: 2.1.4
Linter-ui-default: 1.4.0

### Additional Information

Not sure if it's a problem in linter, but you might want to look into the creation of docks

data.title: Unable to switch the encoding
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Since version 1.17.0 switching encoding to Windows 1251 working incorrectly. Selected encoding changes in the status bar, but cyrillic characters still ���.
 
Also, I have an error in the console: `TypeError: iconv.decodeStream is not a function`.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create file with contents: `абвгдеёжзфывапролджэ`
2. Save file and close
3. Re-open file in the Atom
4. Select Windows 1251 encoding

**Expected behavior:** `абвгдеёжзфывапролджэ`

**Actual behavior:** `���������`

**Reproduces how often:** always

### Versions

1.17.0
1.18.0 beta

data.title: Atom 1.18-beta0 massive memory problem
data.body:
### Description

Upgraded today to  1.18 beta 0 - seems to be big memory problem with just a few open tabs - on my macbook air (4gb ram) which worked fine, albeit a little slowly with 1.17.x. When I open the same project, about 8 tabs, I find over 12GB of memory allocated to Atom Helper (!)  It always was a hog, but bearable, but this isn't bearable. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom (no problem yet)
2. Open my project with ~8 tabs open (now we have a memory problem)
3. Check Activity Monitor in mac

**Expected behavior:** Reasonable memory use, more like 1.17 betas

**Actual behavior:** Massively more memory used, grinding Mac to a halt. 

**Reproduces how often:** 100%, but only after opening a project

Two screens showing 1.18 beta and 1.17, same project, same packages: 

![screen shot 2017-05-16 at 7 34 11 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5451510/26136215/7d7b05d8-3a6f-11e7-9399-d1c5b10bef6b.png)

![screen shot 2017-05-16 at 7 49 44 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5451510/26136445/f0c69e52-3a70-11e7-9d16-ecee0f51f706.png)

### Versions 
Mac OS X Sierra

data.title: Use new native text-buffer implementation
data.body:
### Summary This pull request completely reimplements the `TextBuffer` class - Atom's core data structure representing editable text. The new implementation differs from the old one in several major ways: * The class is now implemented primarily in C++, as part of our native library [superstring](https://github.com/atom/superstring). * Instead of storing the text as a mutable array of lines, we store it as flat immutable string representing the file's original content, plus a *Patch* representing the user's unsaved changes. This is somewhat similar to the [piece table](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piece_table) data structure used in some other editors. * At the native level, the buffer supports *snapshots* - read-only views of the buffer that can be processed in background threads with no copying or locking, even while the buffer is being mutated on the main thread. * File I/O and transcoding is now handled by the native library, entirely on background threads and exposed via promises. ### Motivation For many purposes, the existing array-of-lines implementation was actually very fast; we've never observed slowness associated with the querying or mutating of the text itself. This is a testament to V8's highly efficient String operations. However, there are many operations in Atom that *use* the `TextBuffer` and would benefit from being dropped to C++ and/or being moved to a background thread. Here are some examples of this that have already been addressed in this PR: * Previously, saving and loading a `TextBuffer` required its entire contents to be represented as a single JavaScript String. V8 has a hard limit on string length, so this would cause errors (#7210). Now, saving and loading are done in a background thread in C++, with minimal copying of data. * When the file associated with an unmodified `TextBuffer` changes on disk, we diff the file's new contents with the buffer's contents in order to update the buffer in a way that preserves marker positions. Previously, this diff computation caused unresponsiveness in large files (atom/text-buffer#153). Now the diff is performed in C++ and on a background thread. * Whenever the application is idle, we serialize the state of the window and persist it, so that we can restore it even if Atom crashes or power is lost. Previously, persisting a large file's text would cause hangs, so we had to disable this safety feature for large files (#13583). Now, because of our new representation of the buffer, we are able to efficiently serialize *just* the outstanding changes, so we can re-enable the feature for arbitrarily large files. * The [line-ending-selector](https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector) needs to detect what type of line endings a `TextBuffer` uses. Because we support files with *mixed* line endings, this entails scanning the entire buffer. Previously, this would take upwards of 50ms for a large file. Now, the search is performed asynchronously so that it causes no noticeable lag. In addition to these improvements, this PR will make it very easy to optimize other features. Here are some follow-up PRs that I have in mind: * When changing a large amount of text at once, indexing the new text in the `DisplayLayer` takes a long time. This is one of the main reasons that pasting a huge amount of text is slow. Some of this character-by-character computation could probably be done much faster in C++. * Currently, using the [find-and-replace](https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace) package in a very large file can cause hangs when searches produce more than a hundred thousand results. We will now be able to run searches entirely in a background thread, eliminating any lag. * Populating the [autocomplete-plus](https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus) package's `SymbolStore` can take a very long time for large files, so we had to [disable it](https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/782) for large files. Fuzzy matching should be able to be performed in C++ on a background thread, eliminating this restriction. ### Implementation details
Our new representation of the buffer:
Suppose I create a `TextBuffer` with some initial text and then make three edits: ```js const buffer = new TextBuffer('abc\ndefg\nhijkl') buffer.setTextInRange([[0, 2], [0, 3]], "C") buffer.setTextInRange([[2, 0], [2, 1]], "H") buffer.setTextInRange([[1, 1], [1, 2]], "E") assert.equal(buffer.getText(), 'abC\ndEfg\nHijkl') ``` This buffer is now represented internally like this: ![graph-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/26644547/f3bbc95a-45e9-11e7-91a4-ceee77e90ecc.png) The buffer is composed of two *layers*. The first layer stores the buffer's initial text as a flat, immutable string. This makes freshly-opened files very compact in memory. The second layer stores the unsaved edits in an object that we call a `Patch`. The `Patch` is structured as a [splay tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Splay_tree) so that mutations and queries are very efficient, especially in areas that have recently been accessed. Then, suppose I begin some asynchronous operation like saving the buffer to disk, or searching the buffer for a regex. Then, *while* that operation is still happening, I make some *additional* edits: ```js const savePromise = buffer.save() buffer.setTextInRange([[0, 0], [0, 1]], 'A') buffer.setTextInRange([[2, 4], [2, 5]], 'L') assert.equal(buffer.getText(), 'AbC\ndEfg\nHijkL') ``` At that point, the buffer's internal state would look like this: ![graph2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/326587/26644968/63dd6562-45eb-11e7-9d66-9dfe94d243d9.png) There are now *three* layers. Because the asynchronous `save` is still in progress, further changes that we make to the buffer are saved in a *new* Patch. When the `save` completes, we flatten the text down into one layer again.
### Effect on packages I don't believe making `save` async has affected any of our bundled packages' functionality, though it has caused some test failures that I've had to fix: * [x] https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/852 * [x] https://github.com/atom/whitespace/pull/155 * [x] https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector/pull/45 * [x] https://github.com/atom/symbols-view/pull/222 * [x] https://github.com/atom/status-bar/pull/193 * [x] https://github.com/atom/tabs/pull/448 Depends on https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/225 Depends on https://github.com/atom/superstring/pull/5 Depends on https://github.com/atom/node-pathwatcher/pull/121 Depends on https://github.com/atom/whitespace/pull/157 Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7210 Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11554 Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/11012

data.title: Snapshot + Compile cache breaks linter-xo (and causes some unexpected behaviour)
data.body:
### Description

https://github.com/sindresorhus/atom-linter-xo/issues/74#issuecomment-301923088

Through more investigation in the debugger, the issue isn't seen when
* run in dev mode (which disables snapshots) or
* disabling the NativeCompileCache
  * in the debugger, setting a breakpoint after `NativeCompileCache.install()` (https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/static/index.js#L62) stepping over to the next line, and then running `NativeCompileCache.uninstall()` in the console.

### Steps to Reproduce

install the following packages:
```
» apm ls -i

Community Packages (5) ~/.atom/packages
├── busy-signal@1.4.1
├── intentions@1.1.2
├── linter@2.1.4
├── linter-ui-default@1.4.0
└── linter-xo@0.23.0
```

clone [forivall/node-module-template]

`npm install`

put `'use strict';` in index.js

lint.

**Expected behavior:**

no error should be seen.

**Actual behavior:**

the linter complains that the unicorn rules are not seen.

**Reproduces how often:** always

[screencast](https://imgur.com/a/zBnfy)

### Versions
```
» atom --version && apm --version
Atom    : 1.17.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0
```
OSX 12.2.4

### Additional Information
i also deleted ~/.atom/compile-cache , with no luck.

data.title: "Find in project" output does not show matching lines in all cases
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Using `1.18.0-beta0` downloaded today, I attempted to do a Find In Project. Three files matched; only the first file's lines were displayed. See screenshot. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open project 2. Find -> Find in Project -> enter search term 3. Expand all results. **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] Results should display the instances of the found text. **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] Results do not display all instances of the found text. **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] 100% when the found text is in a comment block. ### Versions 1.18.0-beta0 ### Additional Information see screenshot.

data.title: onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem keeps firing forever until a dock is focused
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you have a `onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem` and have a non-tree-view dock (I tested with linter docks) on boot and don't click on anything, `onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem` will keep firing forever until after 3-4x100 ms after you click a pane item

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install linter
2. Install linter-ui-default @ https://github.com/steelbrain/linter-ui-default/commit/e48b8fbdc0167637f41fd54976a564549eee369c
3. Enable `showPanel` config
4. Open dev tools and reload window

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

`onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem` is invoked only once

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

`onDidStopChangingActivePaneItem` is invoked forever until user clicks a pane Item

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Everytime

### Versions

I've reproduced this on Atom v1.17.0 and v1.18.0-beta0 and Tj Electron Upgrade branch

![kapture 2017-05-17 at 0 05 40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4278113/26124097/b06ee730-3a96-11e7-95e9-3d7da6d4b484.gif)

data.title: Remove 'color' dependency
data.body: This dependency appears to be unused.

data.title: Fix the atom:// URL handler for real (with tests this time)
data.body:
I messed up the fix in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14320 (not sure how I got that to work), since `PackageManager` requires an object in the constructor.
This also adds some real tests so it doesn't break again.

Released under CC0.

data.title: click tree view file,  tree view will scroll.Sometime it click wrong file, not user expect
data.body:
version `1.16.0`
mac `10.12.5 (16F73)`

Click tree view file,  tree view will scroll. Sometime it click wrong file, not user expect.
You can reduce this, if your tree view is expand too many.

data.title: Update some of the out-of-date dependencies
data.body:
### Description of the Change
Two outdated packages (dedent and atom-select-list) were upgraded a minor release (from 0.6.0 to 0.7.0 and from 0.1.0 to 0.2.0 respectively)

### Why Should This Be In Core? / Benefits

Tries to decrease the number of outdated dependencies in Atom. 

### Possible Drawbacks

Needs to pass CI to see if there are no regressions

#### ⚠️ NOTE
I will also try to remove the color dependency since it's unused throughout this repository. I want to first see if this commit passes the necessary tests before trying that out

data.title: Don't show restore dialog for non-editor dock items
data.body:
The Nuclide file tree was causing this dialog to be shown every time.
With this commit, we exclude non-editor dock items from the "dirty"
check.

cc @BinaryMuse @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Remove jQuery from dependencies
data.body:
### Description of the Change
jQuery was removed from `package.json > dependencies` section

### Why Should This Be In Core?

After a search through this repository I found that jQuery isn't being used anywhere but is still part of `package.json` `dependencies`.

### Benefits

Finally removes jQuery from Atom!

### Possible Drawbacks

There may be something still using jQuery in there, so this needs to pass the CI before actually being done
